newsitem.title: USA: IPO HIGHLIGHTS - Edge Petroleum up at debut.
newsitem.headline: IPO HIGHLIGHTS - Edge Petroleum up at debut.

text.p: Four initial public offerings made their debut on Wednesday, with Edge Petroleum Corp the winner of the pack and NACT Telecommunications Inc the surprise loser.
"There were two surprises - Edge Petroleum was up and away, and NACT Telecommunications hit a wrong number," said John Fitzgibbon, editor of the IPO Aftermarket.

Houston-based Edge Petroleum rose two points to 18-1/2 amid sliding secondary markets rattled by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's cautionary comments. Edge, which is engaged in the business of exploring for oil and natural gas, offered 2.4 million shares in a deal led by Raymond James & Associates. The IPO priced at $16.50 per share, in the middle of the $15 to $17 range.

Shares of NACT Telecommunications, which had been seen by some analysts as capable of garnering an opening premium, "broke issue," or fell below its IPO price of $10. Shares were at 9-1/4 in early afternoon trading.

Hambrecht & Quist underwrote the three million share deal, which priced at the bottom of its $10 to $12 range. NACT, a unit of GST Telecommunications Inc, provides advanced telecommunications switching platforms.
Special Metals Inc, a Morgan Stanley deal, rose 1/2 point to 17 on volume of over 3.6 million shares by early afternoon. The stock was among the most heavily traded on the Nasdaq.
Special Metals, a producer of superalloy and special alloy products, offered 3.7 million shares which priced at $16.50 per share, towards the upper end of a $15 to $17 per share range.

Deltek Systems Inc also broke issue, with shares falling below the offer price of $11 to 10-5/8. Montgomery Securities was lead underwriter on the deal. Deltek develops and sells integrated software products for project-oriented businesses.
